name: naphtho[2,3-c]furan-1,3-dione
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-4389
Reason: The basic unit we start with is benzene, which has a melting point around 5.5°C. Substituting functional groups into the benzene ring will affect its melting point. In this case, we have a naphthalene base (fused benzene rings), which by itself has a higher melting point of about 80°C, due to the increased rigidity and planarity of the structure increasing the crystal packing efficiency. The compound in question, naphtho[2,3-c]furan-1,3-dione, contains additional functional groups which further modify its melting point: four carbonyl groups (two ketones and one anhydride) and a furan ring. Each ketone typically increases the melting point by 20-30°C due to intermolecular hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions. The anhydride function will further raise the melting point significantly as it is both polar and can form strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds with itself and other molecules, so we might estimate this for another 40-50°C. The furan ring adds an ether-like functionality which could have a smaller impact, but considering its integration into the naphthalene ring system, it may act to increase rigidity rather than influencing melting point significantly. Therefore, for this ring system, the effect may be negligible or slightly positive, estimated at 5-10°C. Adding these effects together provides an estimated melting point for the compound.
